content.title: Ulcerative Colitis
content.summary: Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease characterized by continuous mucosal inflammation extending proximally from the rectum. Unlike Crohn's disease, UC is limited to the colon and is potentially curable with total colectomy. Management depends on disease extent and severity, ranging from topical aminosalicylates to biologics.
key_points: Continuous inflammation starting from rectum extending proximally (no skip lesions)
Mucosal/submucosal involvement only - NO transmural disease (unlike Crohn's)
Classic triad: Bloody diarrhea, urgency, tenesmus
5-ASA is first-line for mild-moderate disease; biologics for refractory/severe
Colectomy is curative - removes colon cancer risk and disease
content.statement: Ulcerative colitis is a chronic relapsing-remitting inflammatory bowel disease causing continuous superficial colonic inflammation from the rectum, managed with aminosalicylates, immunomodulators, or biologics based on severity, with colectomy reserved for refractory or complicated cases.

explanation.intuition: Think of UC as a 'fire' that always starts at the rectum and spreads continuously upward along the colon like a lit fuse. The fire only burns the surface (mucosa) without going deeper - unlike Crohn's which burns through the entire wall. Because the fire is limited to the colon, removing the colon puts out the fire completely.
explanation.key_insight: The continuous nature and rectal involvement are KEY differentiators from Crohn's. If the rectum is spared or there are skip lesions, it's NOT UC - reconsider Crohn's or other diagnoses. This distinction matters because UC can be cured surgically while Crohn's cannot.
explanation.technical_details: UC involves a Th2-predominant immune response with abnormal barrier function. Crypt abscesses and pseudopolyps are characteristic histologic features. p-ANCA is positive in 60-70% (vs ASCA in Crohn's). Toxic megacolon (transverse colon >6cm) is a life-threatening complication requiring emergent colectomy.

definitions_glossary.ulcerative_colitis: Chronic IBD with continuous mucosal inflammation from rectum proximally
definitions_glossary.proctitis: UC limited to rectum (<15cm from anal verge); E1 classification
definitions_glossary.left_sided_colitis: UC extending to splenic flexure; E2 classification
definitions_glossary.pancolitis: UC extending beyond splenic flexure; E3 classification
definitions_glossary.bloody_diarrhea: Hallmark symptom with mucus and blood mixed with loose stool
definitions_glossary.tenesmus: Feeling of incomplete evacuation; constant urge to defecate
definitions_glossary.crypt_abscess: Neutrophils infiltrating and destroying colonic crypts; histologic feature
definitions_glossary.pseudopolyp: Inflammatory polyp representing regenerating mucosa; not premalignant
definitions_glossary.toxic_megacolon: Acute colonic dilatation (>6cm) with systemic toxicity; emergency
definitions_glossary.aminosalicylate: 5-ASA compounds (mesalamine) acting topically on colonic mucosa
definitions_glossary.total_proctocolectomy: Complete removal of colon and rectum; curative for UC
definitions_glossary.pouchitis: Inflammation of ileal pouch-anal anastomosis; common post-colectomy complication

pathophysiology.mechanism: Dysregulated mucosal immune response with Th2 predominance, defective barrier function, and altered microbiome leading to chronic superficial inflammation

disease_distribution.never: Skip lesions, terminal ileum involvement (except backwash ileitis)
disease_distribution.depth: Mucosal and submucosal only; NOT transmural

histology: Chronic inflammatory infiltrate in lamina propria

Truelove_Witts.mild: ≤4 stools/day, minimal blood, no systemic symptoms
Truelove_Witts.moderate: 4-6 stools/day, moderate blood, minimal systemic symptoms
Truelove_Witts.severe: >6 bloody stools/day, fever, tachycardia, anemia, elevated ESR

diagnostic_workup: Stool studies: C. diff toxin, culture, O&P
Inflammatory markers: CRP, ESR, fecal calprotectin

differential_diagnosis: Crohn's disease (skip lesions, transmural, terminal ileum)
Infectious colitis (C. difficile, Salmonella, E. coli O157:H7)

moderate_severe.induction: Oral corticosteroids (prednisone 40-60mg) or IV methylprednisolone if hospitalized
moderate_severe.steroid_refractory: Biologics (infliximab, vedolizumab, ustekinumab) or JAK inhibitors (tofacitinib)

definition.@value: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease characterized by continuous superficial mucosal inflammation extending proximally from the rectum, manifesting as bloody diarrhea and managed with aminosalicylates, immunomodulators, or biologics

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathophysiology, diagnosis, classification, and management of UC

learning_objectives: Differentiate UC from Crohn's disease by distribution and depth
Classify UC extent using Montreal classification
Assess disease severity using Truelove-Witts criteria
Select appropriate therapy based on extent and severity
clinical_pearls: If rectum is spared, it's NOT UC - reconsider Crohn's
Toxic megacolon = contraindication to colonoscopy, surgical emergency
Colectomy is CURATIVE - discuss with refractory patients
Increased colon cancer risk after 8-10 years of pancolitis
common_misconceptions: UC can involve small bowel - only backwash ileitis, not true involvement
Biologics are first-line - 5-ASA first for mild-moderate
Colectomy is last resort only - can be liberating choice for some patients
